message.content:
<<<api>>>: ImageInfo.java
<<<code>>>: You can use the ImageIO class in Java to get the dpi of an image. Here's an example:

import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.IOException;

public class ImageDpi {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            File file = new File("path/to/your/image.jpg");
            BufferedImage image = ImageIO.read(file);
            int dpi = getDpi(image);
            System.out.println("DPI: " + dpi);
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }

    public static int getDpi(BufferedImage image) {
        int dpi = 0;
        double horizontalResolution = image.getWidth() * 25.4 / image.getWidthMM();
        double verticalResolution = image.getHeight() * 25.4 / image.getHeightMM();
        dpi = (int) Math.round((horizontalResolution + verticalResolution) / 2);
        return dpi;
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In Java, you can use the ImageIO class to read the image file and then calculate the dpi using the image's width, height, and physical size. The getDpi method in the code snippet above calculates the dpi by dividing the image's width and height in pixels by its physical width and height in millimeters, and then converting the result to dpi.

<<<api>>>: ImageInfo.java
<<<code>>>: ImageInfo imageInfo = new ImageInfo("path/to/image.jpg");
imageInfo.check();
int dpi = imageInfo.getDpi();
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the ImageInfo.java library to get the dpi of an image in Java. First, create an instance of ImageInfo with the path to your image. Then, call the check() method to read the image information. Finally, use the getDpi() method to retrieve the dpi value.

<<<api>>>: ImageIO
<<<code>>>: File imageFile = new File("path/to/image.jpg");
ImageInputStream iis = ImageIO.createImageInputStream(imageFile);
Iterator<ImageReader> readers = ImageIO.getImageReaders(iis);

if (readers.hasNext()) {
    ImageReader reader = readers.next();
    reader.setInput(iis);

    int dpiX = reader.getImageMetadata(0).getAsTree("javax_imageio_1.0").getChildNodes().item(0).getAttributes().getNamedItem("HorizontalPixelSize").getNodeValue();
    int dpiY = reader.getImageMetadata(0).getAsTree("javax_imageio_1.0").getChildNodes().item(0).getAttributes().getNamedItem("VerticalPixelSize").getNodeValue();

    System.out.println("DPI X: " + dpiX);
    System.out.println("DPI Y: " + dpiY);
}

iis.close();
<<<explanation>>>: In Java, you can use the ImageIO class to get the DPI of an image. First, create an ImageInputStream using the ImageIO.createImageInputStream() method and pass in the image file. Then, use the ImageIO.getImageReaders() method to get an iterator of ImageReader objects. Check if there is a next reader and get the next reader using the hasNext() and next() methods. Set the reader's input using the setInput() method and then use the getImageMetadata() method to get the metadata of the image. Use the getAsTree() method to get the metadata as a tree and then navigate the tree to get the DPI values. Finally, close the ImageInputStream.

<<<api>>>: ImageInfo
<<<code>>>: String path = "path/to/image.jpg";
ImageInfo imageInfo = new ImageInfo(path);
imageInfo.check();
int dpi = imageInfo.getPhysicalWidthDpi();
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the ImageInfo library to get the dpi of an image in Java. First, create an instance of the ImageInfo class with the path to your image file. Then, call the check() method to read the image file and extract its information. Finally, you can use the getPhysicalWidthDpi() method to get the dpi of the image.

<<<api>>>: ImageInfo.java
<<<code>>>: You can use the ImageIO class in Java to get the dpi of an image. Here's an example:

import javax.imageio.ImageIO;
import java.awt.image.BufferedImage;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.IOException;

public class ImageDpi {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        File imageFile = new File("path/to/image.jpg");
        try {
            BufferedImage image = ImageIO.read(imageFile);
            int dpi = image.getDPI();
            System.out.println("Image DPI: " + dpi);
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: The ImageIO class in Java provides methods to read and write images. You can use the read() method to read the image file into a BufferedImage object. Then, you can use the getDPI() method of the BufferedImage class to get the dpi of the image.

<<<api>>>: ImageInfo.java
<<<code>>>: ImageInfo imageInfo = new ImageInfo("path/to/image.jpg");
imageInfo.setDetermineImageNumber(true);
imageInfo.setCollectComments(true);
imageInfo.setCollectComments(true);
Iterator<ImageInfo.Format> formats = imageInfo.getDetermineImageNumber().iterator();
while(formats.hasNext()){
    ImageInfo.Format format = formats.next();
    System.out.println("Format: " + format);
    System.out.println("Width: " + format.getWidth());
    System.out.println("Height: " + format.getHeight());
    System.out.println("Resolution: " + format.getResolution());
}
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the ImageInfo.java library to get the dpi of an image in Java. First, create an instance of ImageInfo and provide the path to the image file. Then, set the necessary options such as determineImageNumber and collectComments. Finally, use the iterator to iterate over the formats and retrieve the width, height, and resolution of each format.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use the Java Imaging Library (JAI) to get the dpi of an image in Java. Here's an example:

import javax.media.jai.JAI;
import javax.media.jai.PlanarImage;
import java.awt.image.RenderedImage;

public class ImageDpi {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String imagePath = "path/to/your/image.jpg"; // Replace with the path to your image
        
        PlanarImage image = JAI.create("fileload", imagePath);
        RenderedImage renderedImage = image.getAsBufferedImage();
        
        int dpiX = renderedImage.getProperty("dpiX").intValue();
        int dpiY = renderedImage.getProperty("dpiY").intValue();
        
        System.out.println("DPI X: " + dpiX);
        System.out.println("DPI Y: " + dpiY);
    }
}

This code uses JAI to load the image and then retrieves the dpiX and dpiY properties from the rendered image. Make sure to replace "path/to/your/image.jpg" with the actual path to your image file.

<<<api>>>: ImageInfo.java
<<<code>>>: ImageInfo imageInfo = new ImageInfo("path/to/image.jpg");
imageInfo.check();
int dpi = imageInfo.getDpi();
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the ImageInfo.java library to get the dpi of an image in Java. First, create an instance of ImageInfo and pass the path to your image file as a parameter. Then, call the check() method to retrieve the image information. Finally, use the getDpi() method to get the dpi value of the image.

<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can use the Java Imaging Library (JAI) to get the dpi of an image in Java. Here's an example:

import javax.media.jai.JAI;
import javax.media.jai.PlanarImage;
import com.sun.media.jai.codec.FileSeekableStream;
import com.sun.media.jai.codec.ImageCodec;
import com.sun.media.jai.codec.ImageDecoder;
import com.sun.media.jai.codec.SeekableStream;
import com.sun.media.jai.codec.TIFFDecodeParam;

public class ImageDpi {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String imagePath = "path/to/your/image.jpg";
        
        try {
            SeekableStream seekableStream = new FileSeekableStream(imagePath);
            TIFFDecodeParam decodeParam = new TIFFDecodeParam();
            ImageDecoder decoder = ImageCodec.createImageDecoder("tiff", seekableStream, decodeParam);
            PlanarImage image = decoder.decodeAsRenderedImage();
            
            float dpiX = image.getResolutionX();
            float dpiY = image.getResolutionY();
            
            System.out.println("DPI X: " + dpiX);
            System.out.println("DPI Y: " + dpiY);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

This code uses the JAI library to read the image and get its dpi using the getResolutionX() and getResolutionY() methods of the PlanarImage class. Make sure to include the JAI library in your project's dependencies.
